Mode: bottle
Source: roadtrip
Score: 3.9 to 3.6

hazy dark red, fine beige head, streaks of drippy lace, 
body is decent from the beginning, 
lots of bitter dark caramel flavor, biscuit malts offer a bready character but are kept very dry by the earthy bitterness, a bit of sweet citrus is the only sweetness to be found, 

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: **4

Thanks to JasonE for this one.  Clear dbrown color with white head.  Rye, light citrus hops, and caramel in the sweet nose.   Hoppy body with a caramel undercurrent.  Smooth finish.  Hints of tea in the bottle.
Something a bit different and very tasty and pleasant.  Summit hops, plum sugar which gives interesting drinkable characterist while being fresh fruit sweet.  A good showing of rye, with vanilla.

Shared by Trevor at Mullmans gathering.  Amber in color.  Aroma:  heavy citrus, grapefruit, pineapple, caramel and light notes of rye.  Body is medium to full.  Taste is full of citrus, caramel, with notes of rye.  Finishes moderately bitter. For some reason, all of this didnt work too well for me in this particular beer.  enjoyable enough, though.

Tap at the Brew Kettle.  Glowing, firey red-orange hue.  Aroma of burnt cinnamon, caramel, and oranges or tangerines.  Almost a tropical extreme of citrus force.  Very hot on the tongue, like a kind of reduced candy sugar and cayenne soup.  Baked peaches and bourbon intimations in a simmering alcoholic pool.  A green, sprucy bitterness dances tangentially over the hot surface.  Rye is submerged.  Palate has strength but lacks depth.  A big attempt and a small, relative success.

22oz bottle.  Pours a very deep brown with an extremely thin head.  Smell is very sweet with strong hints of caramel and hoppiness -- not unlike a tripel.  Taste is full-bodied and flat with initially sweet flavors of caramel giving way to a  somewhat more tart finish.  An amazingly smooth stong ale well worth a drink.

A subtly earthy, bitter ale with underlying caramel and vegetal notes, it has a much darker-than-expected pour and fuller flavor than most ales. Highly recommended! Best paired alongside meats or potatoes!

Poured from a 22oz bottle into a shaker.  This ale poured a dark brownish amber color with a thick, rocky, beige head that slowly subsided, leaving some extra thick, sticky lacing around the glass.  The aroma was very strong and consisted of a huge floral, citrus hop presence, along with some caramel malt sneaking in behind the hops.  The flavor was decently hoppy and bitter, but the citrus elements appeared to have been mellowed out quite a bit by the palm sugar.  This seemed to give the beer some brandy and vanilla characteristics.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with a slightly slick, oily feel, along with light carbonation.  A very enjoyable and unique beer from Two Brothers.

The color was an amber/orange.  The head was creamy, frothy, and off-white.  The aroma was strong, dry, spice, caramel, and sweet.  The flavor was strong spice, sweet, and raisin.  The palate had a refreshing carbonation.  The finish was dry/bitter.

This came out a bit thick to me.  Enjoyed at Murphys Bleachers, perhaps not the ideal location for this kind of ale, but I was still impressed with the deep mahogany color and long lasting hope aftertaste -- disappointed with the levity.

Thanks to Sprinkle.  This was a different kind of taste for me.  At first I thought it was an IPA, but then it had a strong malt taste too it.  It was a very nice beer with a thick creamy white head.  The lacing was sticking to the glass like glue.  Beautiful red color too.  Very Nice

Thanks hoppymeal! Poured a deep dark reddish with a medium off white creamy head. The aroma is sweet, rich, hoppy, slightly vinous. Not very upfront. The flavor is a little like an imp. ipa, rich, not quite as thick as an imp. Ipa, alcohol is evident, hop bitterness evident, tangy rye flavor, sweet. The palate was average consistency and waxy from the hops.

bomber. a very clean looking ruby colored ale that appears to be heavily carbonated. a soft foamy white head sits atop the beer. resiny hops alcohol and lightly toasted sweetish malts make up the nose. somewhat thin with lots of stinging piney hops and a sort of sugar adjunct. mildly sweet and too much alcohol. not a fan of this one.
Cask @ the Map Room. Brown and orange in colour with a small tan head. Malty with notes of fruit, citrus, pines, caramel and toffee.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2007 22oz bottle-thanks to Heidi&Larry-pours a thin light tan head and dark brown with orange color.  Aroma is nice citrus/pine-hops, wood, secondary medium malt-caramel, and something (OK I needed to read the label) rye.  Taste follows. OK carbonation.

7/6/07: On tap @ Smokehouse   Red buster- brown body with a creamy tan head.  Lace clings to glass all the way to the last drop.  Aroma of fir tree, caramel and toffee.  Flavors of burnt fir tree and toffee.  As beer warms there is a more pronounced flavor of grapefruit and bubble gum.  Finish is long with a black coffee like bitterness.
Pours brown and clear, fine, white head. Strong aroma of hops. Mouth feel is pretty solid with a strong hop flavor with a mild sweet undertone.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2008 22oz, 2007 release, pretty freshly bottled. pours a really nice clear ruby with white head. nose has soap, phenols, butter, and faint hop notes. really gross nose. flavor isnt much better, medicinal, watery hop notes, some biscuit, oh man this is awful. i think theyre having bottling issues because a recent sampling of a fresh hop juice was like this. ill re-rate in several months.2.2. 

3/15/08, bottled a few weeks ago at the facility. pours reddish brown with off white head. nose is very grapefruity, some tropical fruits, citrus, and pine hop notes. very alla Three Floyds. very is loaded with sweet sugary grapefruity hop notes with malty backbone, some rye in there too i guess. my only complaint is the body is pretty watery which seems to make the palate short. otherwise this is a fine graceful ASA.

bottle from dcharms: pours a dark amber colour with a nice size off white head.  aroma is earthy hops, caramel malts and some dark fruits flavour is excellent nice hop bitterness of pine and earth sweet malts with touches of vanilla, rye and some what seems to be cheeries (fresh). the palate is about perfect smooth and creamy and leaving just enough bitterness and dryness to make you want more. fantastic beer. thanks a lot dan.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2007 Red with nice, large off-white head.  Aroma was Hoppy,  roasted malt, doughy, caramel, very nice.  The beer tastes really balanced with a nice piney bitterness and sweet malt, a little cherries and pommegranete come out as well.  Body is smooth, almost creamy and very full.  Overall another great brew from two bros.

This pours a clear dark red, with a thin off white head.  Starts with an aroma of sugar, vanilla, and a hint of rye hiding in there.  This is a tasty hopped up rye ale, with just a hint of sweetness hiding behind the hops.  Fairly light bodied and very drinkable.

Bottle.   Pours a copper color with a medium sized off white head.   Aroma is caramel malts, grapefruit, floral hops.   Flavor is caramel malt, grapefruit, orange, some pine, floral, hint of alcohol and vanilla.   Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, finishes bitter.   A very good brew, defintely towards a IIPA.   I was impressed, this being my first Two Brothers.

Had this one on draught in St. Charles, Illinois.  Deep red pour with a thin but steadfast head, a touch of vanilla, orange and floral hops in the nose, but the real story is the taste, where hoppy dryness meets a strong alcoholic finish.  I was used to it by the end of the pint but it was tough going early on.  Not bad at all!

Bottle.  Sweet cherry/orange hops aroma.  Brown amber color with small head.  Sweet cane sugar flavor up front followed by a light rye malt and finishing with a strong pine/grapefruit hops finish.  Very IPA-like.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2009 Chicago Trip. Friday 20:00. On tap at the Hop Leaf. Foamy head. Bronze to dark amber in colour. Hops and nice sweet spice malt nose. Flavour of caramel toffee, spice, herbs and spruce. A touch hop medicine flavour in the finish. Had a bottle in trade and prefered the tap version which is no surprise.

22oz. Bottle
$5.99
Binnys Orland

Cane and Ebel poured an absolutely crystal clear copper. 1 finger creamy white head formed on the pour that left sheet lacing as it slowly receded. Minimal small slow rising carbonation is present.

The smell is of a solid backbone of caramel with layer upon layer of hoppiness on top. Pine tar and oily resinous hops are showcased in this beer. There is also a unique but mild sugary sweetness from the palm sugar. The sweetness really goes nicely with the resinous hop aroma.

Caramel maltiness comes through up front quickly followed by the resinous hops. The resinous hops linger and get joined by a mild leather flavor thats also from the hops. The caramel maltiness turns into more of a raw graininess as this beer develops on the palate. Finishes with a lingering resinous hops and mild aspirin.

Medium bodied with minimal carbonation lets the beer work its way through at its own pace. Moderately dry finish. Solid hop bitterness leaves the tongue numb which is something I always enjoy.

Im going to polish off this 22 and if I had another bottle I would drink it too. The hops make my mouth water and the dryness makes me want another drink.

Another exciting beer from Two Brothers. Ive been looking for this for awhile and finally found it. Glad I did. A really enjoyable hoppy rye beer.

3/24/07

had this a couple of times and never rated.  aroma is citrus and pineapple hoppy with sweet rye peeking in there.  taste is caramel sweet grapefruit at first yielding rye dryness that perfectly compliments the hop bitterness. i really enjoy these rye beers especially when used in conjunction to a healthy hopping.

This h opped up rye ale is dry, is hoppy, is good.  It does not have a great body, but as the beer warms it does start to gain a caramelly vanilla flavor.  Probably due to the sugar and malt.  The rye adds a certain additional spiciness that accentuates the bitter, citric hops.  Overall, this beer is not very complex due to the dominance of hops versus the very thin body.  Id expect this out of an IPA, but a I expect more out of a red ale.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2012 Dark red with a nice lasting beige head.  Notes of cotton candy, earthy and citrus hops in the aroma.  Mild grapfruit, earthy, some roast, mild caramel, and hops dominated flavour.  Medium bitter with a dry hop finish.

Clear dark-amber body topped by a short-lived beige head leaving good lacings.  Roasted rye bread and tree barks soaked in citrus/lemon juice.  Well hopped and the resulting hop flavour is pleasantly unfocussed.  Bitterness is of medium intensity.  The gentle malt sweetness feels 2/3 caramel and 1/3 maple.  Some dried fruits.  A little dryness combined with a medium tartness really increases drinkability, after a 660ml I wanted more.  Very good beer.  As far as 7% hopped-rye beers are concerned I prefer the Founders Red Rye but these are two different beasts.  If anything Id label the Cane and Ebel as a Bear Republic Hop Rod Rye Light.  Similar flavour spectrum, just less intense.  I love well hopped rye beers.  There are better things in life than hopped rye beers, but hopped bye beers makes up for not having them.

Had this on tap at Barleys The Smokehouse.  Beautiful nose of grapefruit, lemon & lime.  This brew is a dark ruby copper.  The off-white super creamy head is mostly lasting and leaves behind a light curtain of lace.  The flavor is mostly bitter with the trademark snappy rye sourness, very nice.  The full body is soft & dry.  This is a really good beer, and grossly underrated IMHO.  I guess on tap must be the way to go.

Clear reddish-copper with a small head. Fair lace. Aroma of citrus, cantaloupe and caramel. Taste was caramel and toffee almost covering up the spicy rye and citrus hops. Could do with less sweetness. Weird chalky and astringent finish.

22 oz bottle: Bit hazy red/brown color with tiny light tan head. Aroma is soapy, bit of caramel and faint herbal hops. Flavor has fair amount of kilned, munich-type malts, with caramel, vanilla, faint spiceyness from the rye. Finish is balanced, palate is a bit thin. Overall a good brew, although I dont get much rye coming through, and I really dont get any of the simcoe that they aparrently dry hop with. I feel like they could have done more with this than they did.

Dark tea red-brown, tan styrofoam head.  Cask at Clarke St Ale House, Chicago.  Grapefruit, malt, IPA aroma.  Super fruity, fairly sweet.  Chalky, very lightly salty.  Precipitous finish -- falls off rapidly then trails. An interesting hopping, fruity without much bitterness.  Medium body.

Bottle.  Poured an auburn and copper; medium to large head.  Aroma of citrus hops and rye.  Flavor struck me as weird and metallic initially.  Got much better.  Flavor of hops, malt and rye; nice balance.  Smooth and nice mouthfeel.
Bottle.  Aroma mostly of citrus hops and some grain.  The flavor is sweet and kind of like caramel malt with a slightly metallic bitter finish.  The flavor mellows after a bit, and seems decent.

Solid copper color.  Ah hops how I love thee!  Big bold flavor exploding in my mouth.  Excellent malt and oat characteristics.  I could drink this all day.  Great mouth feel pops with bubbles slightly acidic and  medium finish.  Thick  Butter cookie, floral aroma.  Wonderful.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2007 On tap at Map Room and Hop Leaf in Chicago.  Ill admit-- I wasnt expecting much.  Ive found Two Brothers beers to be fairly conservative and true to style.  But this oen surprised me.  It is an outstanding rye beer-- I wouldnt mind even a little more of the rye flavor.  Tastes very fresh on tap and really pops in your mouth with a nice complexity of flavors, but still balanced.  Very unique taste and would make for a great session beer.  Good job to a local brewery.

I love rye beers (Founders Reds Rye has been my favorite beer for awhile now), so I was thrilled to try this one.  It is very good...its hoppy character is balanced nicely by the rye flavor, and it is fairly complex in both its flavor and mouthfeel.  It is very good, and I would definitely recommend.

It poured a sparkling red with only a little head that hung around a bit.  It has a rye-ish (like othe rye beers) and hoppy aroma, with some cedar notes that reminded me of some Hitachino I had a while back.  Flavor is dry-hoppy, hop-citrusy, with just a touch of sourness.  The sugar imparts a cotton-candy flavor as well.  Mouthfeel is slightly scratchy in your mouth, which is pleasant.  It is somewhat chalky in texure, but soft at the same time.  Very interesting.

Bottled - poured in one of Sam Adams new special glasses (an English pint?). This beer pours the color of a really dehydrated mans urine.  It has a very nice white head that sticks around for a while.  It smells of hops, hops and maybe a touch of hops.  It has a very dry and hoppy (surprise) taste that causes you to burp pure hops.  There might be a touch of fruit in there, buried deep and hunching down around a secret center.  I dont taste any caramel.   I dont taste much of anything other than hops.  Im afraid Im terribly disappointed in this beer.   Im a fan of hops.  No, really I am.  Its just that his beer has nothing to balance it.

Thanks to iowaherkeye for this one via Mystery Swap 2.0.  Pours hazy ruby/deep coppery with 1-finger off-white head and lasting sheets of lace.  Aroma is caramel malty, with big hops, some rye, cabernet, and berry notes.  Tastes caramel malty, with a solid hop bill matched by rye, cabernet, black pepper, and some pumpernickly finishing notes.  Rich palate.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2007 Pours a syrupy mahogany color with a small frothy off white head.  Sweet hoppy aroma with hints of fruit loops.  Starts off with a mild sweetness still comparable to fruit loops that becomes quickly hidden behind a nice shot of hops with a sort of dry, rye finish.

Jason and Jim are great guys and Im glad to taste something that really makes me want to buy a case-a keg-some large amount.  Their beer has always been very well made, but I feel as though their palates and mine look for different things.  This is a nice hoppy beer with a lot going on.  Im a big fan of rye beers and this does not dissapoint.  I dont like to dissect beers, but this has the aroma, good hop presence and plenty of malt to keep it together.  Me love the cane!

Darker amber, fairly large head with solid lacing and retention. Aroma is very hoppy with loads of fruits, vanilla, caramel, bread. Medium to light body, not very bitter and quite drinkable. Enjoyable.

22 oz. bottle. poured deep copper with small white head. nice lacing in glass. Aroma of black pepper spiced grapefruit and toast. Startswith a rounded peppery flavor which quickley makes way for a strong fresh bisquity flavor then heading to the pungent citrus bittering balance mentioned on the label. finishes on the bitter side, but wanting more. A solid effort by the Ebels

Bottle from the Spirit Haus. To me, this beer is better described as an imperial amber ale, similar to a nugget nectar or big hoppy monster. But its not quite as hoppy as either of those.  A nice session beer no doubt, but just kind of boring.

Pour is a dark red with a large white head. Aroma is strong amounts of rye with some hops to balance out the bitterness. Flavor is a nice mix of hops and cane sugar. tingles all the sences... Of all the "rye" beers i have had this is prob the only one i could actually taste and smell the rye used. Very good and satisfying. this ones  for my pAl...rayboy01

This rockin rye is a full-bodied (chewy)  ale with a nice balance of sweet, biscuity rye malts, sugary sweet tanginess from the sugar additions, and bright citrusy hop bite from the Summit hops.   Quite nicely brewed and very nice indeed hand-pulled off the engine!

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2007 let me start off by saying THIS BEER ROCKS- pours a dark cloudy apple cider color with a one finger, quickly disappearing off white head. aroma is of sweet sugary hops. medium to heavy body with descent lacing and carbonation. flavor is sweet sugary hops with a little rye. has a dry hop aftertaste that lingers. very awsome hoppy beer one of the best i have had from two brothers so far! also has a pine and orange peel aroma and flavor as well. this is one of the greats i think and i have had a few already a must try. i also noticed as it warms there is some mango that comes thru in the aroma and flavor.

22 oz bottle, thanks to iowaherkeye.  Pours a slightly hazy orangish amber with a thin off white head.  Spicy aroma, with a backdrop of citrus and earthyness.  Nice malty, yet quite bitter flavor, a little unbalanced, but still quite good.  Not a whole lot of rye, I would have liked more, but it is still quite nice.  Medium mouthfeel and a lingering finish.  A nice beer, but if your gonnaput rye in it, load it up!
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text:
Thanks to Nuclear George for this one. :banned:

Rye brews are one of my favorites now. This one jsut solidifies their placement in my rankings. A very good brew.. The smell was a little weak but other than that it no drawbacks. An overall great brew..

Bottle: Cark amber body with a low amount of head.  Aroma is sweet, with molasses, maple syrup notes, in addition to the pine and floral hop qualities.  Noted a little bit of rye-like spicyness.  In the mouth, this beer started out sweet with molasses abd vanilla notes.  Fruity notes followed, with mellon flavors dominating, followed by a spicy hop finish, with lingering pine qualities.  Not a bad beer, but I was hoping for more rye-like qualities.

Bottle from both Duane and Ughsmash. Mahogany with minimal head. Huge caramel and cardboard aroma, old oxidized hops. Flavor on par, cardboard comes through even more though. Faint citrus hop bitterness in the finish. Mouthfeel rather thin. Tad dissapointed.
lots of rye and some citrus and some grapefruit.  some sugar and honey with a little malt and some yeast

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2007 Hazy reddish pour with big bright pink highlights, cool looking. White head with good retention. Looks very thick, sugary and menacing. Hoppy as all get out, plenty of rye in the nose as well. Citrus aromas of pineapple, grapefruit, pine needles, a little mint. Sugary notes and malt take the back seat but are there for sure. Flavor has a great amount of rye, well done! Also less sugar, just enough to balance the hop assault. Seems to be very well balanced. Only the second beer of many from this brewery I found to be very well made. Good job, killer rye component. More.

Courtesy Degarth. Deep ruby and a modest, frothy tan cap. Nose of huge resinous, venomous hops and subtle sweetness and grain. Similar flavor, nice rye and light fruitiness. Almost vanilla like sweetness on the end. Medium/full body, balanced palate. Solid, hopped up red.

Bottle and served in a pint glass: Pours a coppery hue with a small fading head but had good lace. The aroma is a nice blend of spicy hops, rye, pineapple, biscuit, and vanilla bean. The taste is a sharp combination of rye snap and bitter hops with a backing chorus of acidic fruit tones finishing with a touch of mineral astringency. I really dig this beer...why did I wait so long to rate it? This does what is should do, showcase the Rye!
22oz bottle. Reddish golden color, a bitter and spicy brew due to the rye and high AA hops. This beer has the most rye taste I have had to date. The hops fit nicely with the spice of the rye.

(Tap at the Brewery) Pours a dark copper color. Aroma is very hoppy with some citrus mixed in as well. Dry mouthfeel balances the beer out wonderfully. Malts also add some roasted nut notes. Full mouthfeel. An excellent beer!

1 pint 6 fl.oz. bottle. Deep reddish brown. Clear. Small, but creamy off-white head that clings to the glass. Rich and pungent toasted malt aroma with a strong hoppy background. Nutty and slightly sweet reminiscent of marzipan. Mellow at first, but then the hops set in. Rich roasted and toasted malt character. Quite impressive. Medium-bodied. Light prickly feeling in the finish. Finishes gently with a wonderfully mellow bitterness. A bit thin finish perhaps.

Bottle:  Courtesy of Styles.  The aroma has lots oc caramel with some faint banana bread and a hint of oxidized hops.  The beer pours a transparent reddish-orange with a small white head.  The flavor starts with lots of caramel, toffee, and hints of banana bread.  The finish has some light oxidized hop flavors.  Its solid, but Id like to try this fresh as the oxidation is not a good thing in this beer.

Bomber from Archer Liquors.

Very nice looking beer with a ruddy chestnut hue and a firm and lasting, two finger thick, off-white head. Aroma is massive citric hops with notes of pine and strong herbal tinctures.

Fore is less hoppy tasting than the aroma indicates. Its actually almost light-bodied with a watery start that transitions into mild and dry malt flavors, light orange peel notes and some hearty baked bread notes. The aftertaste is more of the orange peel hops. Its fairly thin all the way through compared to the other big rye beers.

Amber body with a thin head. Crisp hoppy aromas with notes of caramel. Flavors of caramel, toffee and slight hints of grapefruit are backed nicely by strong hops. Smooth, crisp hops carry through the finish, which contains somewhat of an earthy, well-water aftertaste.

2006 bottle (17.0 Plato, 68 IBU, 7.0% ABV)... 

According to the label, Two Brothers Cane and Ebel is "A Hopped-Up Red Rye Ale."  I would say that it lives up to that description nicely!  It pours a nice clear amber color ("peach-copper-brown" according to my wife) with a slight reddish hue.  Moderate amount of carbonation with a fluffy tan head.  It collapses kind of quickly, the the remaining crown provides ample lacing throughout the duration.  The aroma is of rye and sweet fruity (orange/citrus) hops and malt.  The flavor is much like the aroma, with a deep caramel maltiness and a substantial, but well-balanced citrus/pine hop bitterness.  The rye comes back out in the lengthy, slightly dry finish.  Llike most other rye beers, this one is slighty heavier than average on the palate smooth and creamy going down!  

-- I love rye beers and this is another fine example.  Overall I would place it as a close runner-up to Founders Reds Rye and Terrapin Rye2...  

22 oz bottle from Rivers Bend.  -- 

An update on this beer from the Two Brothers web site: "Due to overwhelming demand, we have brewed Cane and Ebel again...  Bottles of Cane and Ebel will be available sometime in January [2007]."

Pours a glorious auburn red with a thick, rocky white head.  Sweetish malts waft from the head with hints of perfume andlight citrus.  A myriad of flavors hits you with the first sip - sweet caramel apples with the sting of rye, followed by some tangy pine and citric hoppiness, som strawberry like fruitiness at the swallow.  Fairly full bodied and a pleasure to imbibe.

22 oz bottle:  Light coppery brown w/ a lasting cream colored head.  Immediate aroma that jumps out at me, beside piney/citrusy hops is actually caramel.  Grassy/resiny hop aromas.  Rye is light, but plays well with others (hops) as well as a hint of bready malt gets stronger as it warms.  Well balanced w/ a strong piney hop flavor.  A slight edge to bitterness in the semi dry finish.  Caramel and rye malts balance hop flavor well, but it is hop dominated throughout and lasts into the aftertaste.    Not a whole lot of fruitiness going on here, just lots of hops.  Medium carbonation, fuller medium body, smooth m/f, well hidden alcohol.  Nice beer, lots of hops, but balanced well  w/ malt flavors to keep it from becoming hop juice...Quite tasty!
Poured an amber color with good head below average lacing.  Aroma was of rye hops and caramel.  Flavor was much the same.  The aftertaste came up a little sweet for me.  Not bad
Brown body with no head.  Aroma is sweetly malty.  Taste is of sweet tea, light malts and some grass.
Brought to the Richmond Beer Industry Gathering 2006. Dark amber body with a small white head. Sweet malty aroma with some mild floral hops. Sweet floral hop flavor with a very smooth ending.

Pours a clear bright copper bronze with a forthy, well-lacing off-white head.  Aroma boasts fresh grapefruity hops and some sweet caramel malt.  Body starts with a healthy dose of sweet toasty crystal malt and a touch of rye toward a drier bittersweet flavor hoppy finish.  Nicely balanced and interesting brew.

Poured amber-red in color, decent initial head, good retention, unimpressive lacing. The aroma was bready, caramel, spicey hoppy rye. The flavor  followed suit, pretty crisp and sharp initially (40-45F) with increasing caramel sweetness a light fruity esters as it warmed. The increasing sweetness kept this from being excellent or distinguished from its near peers Ive rated, but it was a pretty solid and enjoyable beer nonetheless. Mouthfeel was full and hearty.
A very sublime beer. A malty, fruity scent with a dry, malty watery finish. Tastes to me like a brewpub smells. Drinkable in the extreme

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a small sized head of foamy tan colored bubbles that was mostly lasting and left behind a transparent typically carbonated caramel brown colored body and a fair lacing. The mild aroma was hoppy bready and Irish Red malty. The crisp and clean mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a biting hoppy aftertaste. The mild flavor contained notes of mild hops hops breads and caramel. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

Bottle.  Pours a rich ruby red with a thin off-white head that laces copiously.  A sweet aroma of hops, with an underlying spiciness.  You can taste the sweetness imparted by the rye and hops before the beer finishes bitter.
22 oz bottle.  Clear ruby orange with a dense off-white head.  Bready hops and cane sugar.  Creamy hop-rye combo.  Both come back to leave some bite and drying.  A little orange and apple in between.

Smallish offwhite head over deep red body. Sweet, sharpish, wild berry aroma with rye malt notes. Deep, firm malt sweetness. Taste is nutty rye malts with hop background. Bitterish, but not too bitter. Bitter sugary taste lingers. Quite simple, but reasonably good. (0.65l bottle.)

Marked on RB as a spring release, but this one just showed up at my local store.  Deep, deep amber pour with a incredibly dense head that is almost nitro like at first.  The head settles into a lace inducing ring, leaving in its place a fantastic nose.  The hops are quite citrusy, but seem almost "meaty" at times - really heavy and quite pungent.  A great, earthy rye note carries throughout the beer.  The body does thin out near the finish - but overall a solid built beer.

Cold 22oz bottle:  
Pors a clear dark red amber with a small bubbly tan head that mostly dissolves.   Roasted malts, floral hops, dark fruits, brown sugar and spice.  Full bodied, with good carbonation.  Oily texture with a long dry bitter & floral aftertaste.

Bomber:  Pours a clear ruby orange with a thin off-white head, piney hops and rich malts in the aroma with some cinnamon and lemon, medium to thin bodied with soft carbonation, starts and ends bitter.
UPDATED: NOV 17, 2006 Not a bad red but I have had better.  Like grimreeser the almighty said before me, it is lacking something.   Hey grimreeser,  GFY FNG.
Pours a dark red with a thin but nice looking off white head. Nice aroma, fruity hops and some caramel. Fairly strong bitterness, flavor seems to be lacking a little something.

Bomber.  The beer pours to a clean red body with a very creamy looking gray/white head.  The aroma is strong with lots of grapefruit hops and lightly toasty rye malt.  Some light nectarines are apparent.  The flavor is really malty with bitter grassy hops.  Notes of toffee.  The palate is rich with a strong bitterness and light chalkiness.

Bomber purchased at the Corkscrew in Urbana, probably 4 months ago. It strikes me that this would continue to age well, and it reminded me a lot of Arrogant Bastard. Notes of caramel and vanilla sweetness with a bracing hop finish. Underrated on this site in my opinion. The rye adds a great flavor, and I would go with this over the Terrapin beers. Bring on the strong ales made with rye!

Thanks to Notalush for sharing his bomber with me!  Dark copper body, with a quickly fading head...a very malty, slightly roasty aroma, without much evidence of hops.  The flavor picks up some hop flavor, although it is still mild.  The finish however, is pleasantly bitter and refreshing.  Smooth and creamy.  Not much carbonation.

Medium ruby pour, with minimal lace - very malty aroma, with notes of toasted bread and vanilla - a little too sweet overall, but there is enough dry bitterness to keep it somewhat in check - the rye is quite present, along with some bready malt to give it a multigrain bread kind of taste - the plum sugar is noticable, combining with some vanilla flavor to give the beer a unique touch - I would still like it to be a little less sweet.

Bomber.  Pours dark red with a creamy off white head. Aroma of vanilla , tropical fruit, and rye. Rich Toasted malt backbone with touch of rye and maple syrup sweetness. Medium bitter finish, with more rye coming out. Reminds me of a maltier version of Founders Reds Rye. Not too shabby. Best beer from Two Brothers so far

pours dark ruby red with a nice off white head that sticks around forever and leaves nice lacing. aroma roasted malt quite a bit of vanilla and caramel (nice creme brulee accent)  and light citrus hops. big sweet toasted malt flavor with a bit of vanilla. flavor fairly balanced. good hop backbone. nice prickly spice throughout.  the sweet malt flavor fades away gently leaving you with a bitter toasted spicy hoppy finish. the finish is good it just needs some balance. medium body. lively carbonation. good beer. it would be great if the finish were more well rounded.
22oz bomber-A nice medium amber with a head that dissipated into a ring. Aroma of caramel,malt, and hops. Taste of hops, citrus and more hops. A nice tasting beer.

Bottle, purchased at Sams, Chicago - Aug 2006. Pours dark red/mahogany with a slightly hazy appearance and quickly fading head. Aroma of caramel, fresh wort and a little grapefruit. Flavor has notes of dark caramel, toffee, pine, spiciness, bread and a lot of resinous hop bitterness. Medium smooth body with lively carbonation. Not bad but needs some tweaking.

Rust / medium-dark orange-red. Lingering creamy off-white head. Aroma has sweet rye malts, light nice perfumey hops, Lake Michigan seaweed. Taste is a pleasant sweet hop concoction. Fruity sweet perfume. Some caramel rye. Pretty good overall, but nothing I havent seen before. Still, nice to see a good beer from Two Brothers.

22 oz. bottle: Pours dark brown with an off-white head that is quick to diminish but leaves nice lacing. Aroma is hoppy with hints of citrus. Taste is sweet, fruity, and spicy that has a dry hoppiness from start to finish. Has a creamy and thin feel on the palate. Well balanced yet a very complex brew. Interesting and delicious!

Sample at Brew Kettle: Dark amber color with a thin beige head. Sheets of lacing at the top of the glass, and thinner layers below. Aroma of rye, malt and hops. Medium-bodied with a bready malt and rye flavor, along with a good amount of hops and fruit. The finish is spicy with hops and a touch of alcohol. Solid all around.

On tap at he Brew Kettle in Strongsville, Ohio 9/12/06. Deep copper with a large, light tan head and beautiful lace.. Hoppy aroma with spice, citrus, and pine. Smooth with a medium body and some chewiness.. Brwon sugar and caramel balanced by grapefruit and bitter orange rind leaving a long and bitter finish.

22oz bomber-carmel amber with a small off-white head.  pretty decent looking brew.  light dark fruits on the nose along with some small rye character.  some faided citric hop notes as well.  metallic hops and some decent rye character shine in the flavors.  however, the beer is not bright and bursting with flavor as i was expecting from the reviews.  the rye shows up more in the finish especially when it warmed up a bit.  some green/earthy hops on the flavor, but again, they are restrained.  fairly balanced beer, but nothing very shocking.

Bottle. Small ivory head that diminished fully, decent lacing, carbonation, transparent, and a red hue with an orange tint to it. Caramel, hoppy and malty nose. Flavor consisted of caramel, malt, hop and very dry tasting. Mouthfeel was hoppy and yet dry. Medium body. Just too hoppy for my palate. A hopheads delight IMO.

Great beer.  I am a big fan of Founders Reds Rye.  This is the same style of a brew, but just a bit better product in my opinion.  It is has a better hop profile.  Almost like a mixute of centinnial and simcoe hops, but dont quote me on that.

Bomber carried out here by a friend from Boston.

Pours a deep caramelly brown, reddish-orange highlights with a nice tan head and decent lacing. The aroma though dominated by very nice, powerful resin-and-citrus hops, is quite sweet. A light confectionary sugar rests on top; underneath all of those hops there is some burnt sugar, more fruitiness, a faint hint of rye, notes of lime, and unfortunately on just a few sips I also pick up a whisper of a cough-syrup base. 

The flavor is a nice mix of dark caramel sugars and up-front citrus rind hops. Theres a bit of vanilla cream soda in here; rye notes add some spicy interest to the finish which works wonderfully between the rye spices, the Summit bitterness, and the residual sugars. I might describe this as Hop Rod Lite, but that almost sounds derogatory when it is intended otherwise. Like the over-the-top Hop Rod this is an excellent beer, but here balance plays a much bigger role in the overall appeal; my only complaint is that it may be just a notch too sweet on the tail end of the flavor profile.

For whatever reason, I had relatively high hopes for this beer, but even given those high hopes its a very pleasant surprise to find out just how good this one is. I really wish this was available locally; it could easily become one of my house beers.

A dark red amber pour with an off white head.  An aroma of much hops and sweetish malts. A big hoppy flavor with not as much maltiness as I expected, but still some light malt sweetness. A nice carbonation and mouthfeel. Thanks to Jhop or Solong at kps

Reddish-brown pour.  Very nice hoppy aroma reminiscent of a good IPA.  Taste is sweet malts with pleasant rye in there (but not overwhelmingly so!)  Hops are very good from start to finish.  Summit+Simcoe=good stuff.  Very unique beer that is very drinkable and deserves a few extra style points.  Will purchase again when Im back in the Chicago area!

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, jerc, mds & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a clear ruby-copper with an average size semi-lasting off-white head. Nice hoppy aroma well balanced with caramel malt along with some hints of rye. Flavour of citrus and spruce hops along with rye malt and a nice bitter finish. Alcohol is well hidden. Medium bodied. Quite enjoyable and incredibly easy to drink.

Pours a nice copper-red color with a small head that faded quickly.Has a great caramel aroma thats pretty strong,but under that you can smell a little hop/citrus aroma.Taste of hop and rye.I was expecting more of a malt backing though.....kinda thin. Has a nice bitter finish to it. Not Bad!

Earthy nose. Lively carbonation. Sweet and juicy hops, with grass, pine and citrus. Snappy bitterness, but it didnt seem to linger. Malt flavors were light, with some faint hints of grain, crackers and toast. Not too shabby.

Bottle shared with the regular crew plus MDS, at Gregs, bottle courtesy of Harry.  Dark ruby amber, foamy thick white head.  Lots of bready malt and hops in strong pleasing aroma.  Neat foamy medium mouthfeel.  Really nice soft taste - malt, lots of hops.  Complimentary alcohol.  Some rye notes as well.  A text book American strong (along the rye angle), very good.

Bottle. Pours a clear copper body with an off-white head. The aroma is very resiny and fruity - grapefruit and sweet chewiness. The body is pretty chewy too with pine flavour. There is plenty of rye bread and palatable piney bitterness in the finish. Mild alcohol warmth.

Bottle shared with blankboy, HogTownHarry, jerc, tupalev & mds - HogTownHarrys bottle. Bright ruby-amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is hoppy, but not agressively so, with a good caramel malt balance, and a bit of rye. Flavour holds a good balance of grapefruity & sprucey hops, and a full malt backbone. A good strong ale that would make for a pleasant - if slightly drunken - session.

Dark amber brown with a decent off white head. Big hoppy aroma, leafy green hops. Moderate bitterness, light nots of grainy rye. Average palate. Doesnt pop but is quite quaffable. 
7-8/3/7/3/14+

Pours a beautiful dark ruby red hue with bubbles cascading up to a frothy caramel head. The aroma was all hops and rye. Pungent dank hops. Citrus zest, toffee, breadiness, with some spice. The aroma was DAMN good. Upon tasting my tongue was greeted with a heavy hand of sweet caramel toffee, biscuit, and citrus hops...wow. This stuff is good. Bitterness kept everything in check and made this a very easy beer to heavily imbibe at one time. I think I drank my pint in about 5 minutes. It was too damn good. Alcohol was well hidden. Mouth feel left a little to be desired but didnt detract too much from the overall experience.

What are the odds that youll rate two consecutive beers with the same number of ratings (65)? Hop aroma with sweet, dark fruit notes and rye evident. Slightly hazy body with rapidly rising bubbles. Wonderful appearance. Off-white head. Beautiful lace. Really a top notch appearance. Initial mouthfeel is disappointing. Doesnt live up to its aroma. Has some good aspects and improves as it warms. Two Bros can do better than this. A 7% abv brew with 68 IBU should have more balance and have a stronger hop profile. That said, this is one of those brews where the entire bottle should be poured into a large glass as it improves when the sediment/yeast, etc. gets poured into the glass. Takes on a creaminess not previously detected. I wish, however, that I had tasted this brew at the Great Taste of the Midwest, where it would have only cost me approx. $1 instead of plunking down $5.49 plus tax at the liquor store for a bomber. Definitely over priced.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2006 Bottle (650ml).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow, jerc, mds and tupalev, my bottle.  Poured clear bright copper with a decent head - 4/5 for that colour!  Hoppy aroma, I got a mix of citrus, sweet rye malt, spruce, fresh tangerines, mild alcohol presence - hoppy yet juicy and sweet as well, not aggressive.  Flavour was a little milder than expected, rye, sweet toasty malt, spruce/resin hops, nicely balance - a little watery in the finish, but nicely astringent and lightly carbonated and alcoholic mouthfeel - sinfully easy to drink, well done and Id have it again for sure.

Bottle. Hazy red/brown color with a small beige head. Really nice aroma of pine, black tea, rye and a bit of caramel malt. The sweetness of the malt comes out more in the flavor. I stil detect the tea, though not as strong. Pine, rye bread and just a touch of alcohol round out the flavors.

Pours clear reeddish brown with little or no carbonation. How do you describe the smell of rye?? Aroma is hoppy and rye scented for sure. I like the flavor of these rye brews specially when the are hopped up.

Simcoe really shines through in this beer and covers up many of the other flavors.  Aroma is moslty hoppy with some solvent like aromas with rubber and light sulfur hints.  Flavor is sweet caramel malts, light herbal and bready rye.  Finishes light and dry with a bit of astringency.  Pretty good overall.  Nice use of hops, but isnt very complex despite the palm sugar additions.

Draft.  Aroma:  Rye spiciness, caramel, lots of resin and pine, a sweet citrus aroma, and a slight grassy note.  Appearance:  Deep copper approaching brown.  Light beige head was full and frothy.  Good head retention and lots of lacing.  Flavor:  Nice semi-sweet caramel malt, touch of toasted grain, rye, big resin and pine hop flavors with notes of grapefruit.  A touch of vanilla right before the finish.  Bitterness lingers for a bit, but not too long.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Lively carbonation.  Finish was sweeter than I was expecting, but not bad.  Overall:  This is a good one.  Well crafted with some good solid flavors.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2006 Pours a rich clear reddish brown with a big, though diminishing slightly offwhite head.  the nose is mellowed by a creamy sweetness accompanying a well rounded malt.  Assertive spicey rye and slightly more subdued grapefruit hop aromas provide balance.  The palate is smooth with good weight in the mouth.  A rich creamy dark sweetness akin to molasses is the first flavor noticable.  Spicy rye notes and grass enter seamlessly, easing aside to those citrus/grapefruit hops.  The lingering bitterness is complex, thanks to the hops and rye, but still clean.  Interestingly enough, I feel like the sweetness really sticks around.  Over time, the flavors started to remind me more and more of a cold cup of hot tea, this kind of bugged me, causing me to lower the flavor by 1 point.  This is still incredibly pleasant to drink, in my opinion.

In flavor, this beer has big hops, big rye, super sweet, with pine, fruity, caramel, lemons, also spicey and bitter.  The aroma is similar but dominated by the rye, citrus and hops.  Oh, emphasis on the big hops!  So, theres a lot going on in this beer, but its very well-balanced and nothing is out of place.  Above average in appearance, with a deep red color, and a small dense white head.

Bottle... Clear copper ale with a small, creamy, off-white head. Big Simcoe® (cat piss) aroma with lesser notes of caramel and pine. Spicy, tongue numbing (novocaine) bitterness... not overly bitter, just numbing. A whisper of salt. Medium-bodied with lively carbonation. Bitter, dry finish. A big SHOUT goes out to WBC for shipping the bottle!

Pours amber to brown with a patchy off-white head.  Aroma is huge floral and pine hop juice, malt (meal, grain), caramel and wheat, rye yeast.  Caramel grainy malt, hoppy fruit, pine hops, bready rye, dry at the end.  Medium bodied, smooth palate that goes dry at the end.

22oz bottle via trade with Duane! - Thanks! - Pours copper with a fair sized creamy offwhite head taht stays pretty well and laces the sides of the glass..  Aroma is grapefruit hops, a touch of caramel, and some dark sugar.  Flavor is quite sweet with that dark sugar, and caramel, but the bitter grapefruit and pine notes from the c-hops blend wonderfully with the sweetness.  Very balanced, medium bodied.  Creamy palate.  Good bitter finish.  This is a nice brew..

Bomber. Thanks Crosling. Beer is a medium red-amber color with a small, white, frothy, mostly and rapidly diminishing head. The aroma is malty with moderate notes of toasted grain, toasted cracker,rye flour, caramel; Hoppy with heavy notes of resin/pine, moderate note of dried apricot, clean dry straw; Yeasty with trace note of cool cellar, intermittent trace of sweat sockbut not in a dimensional way, not in a bad way. Miscellaneous traces of vanilla and stone fruit. The flavor was moderately sweet, moderately-to-heavily bitter with an average-length, moderately bitter/grippy finish.
The body is medium, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

Bottle. Small head. Dark red, clear body. Nice rye, hop aroma. Taste is hearty bitter hops, touches of resin. Wonderful mouthfeel, soft and approachable. Balanced sweetness. Well rounded beer, no major flaws at all.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2016 Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark amber.

Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, molasses), lightly hoppy (flowers), with notes of toffee, brown sugar, and carpet.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Clunky and aimless, like most things Ive had from this brewery.

22 oz bottle, fairly fresh: dark (though clear) brown amber with a thin, persistent taupe head.  Strong rye-hop bitterness in the aroma, with sugary undertones and a medicinal herbal quality.  Strong (a bit overstated) almost fizzy carbonation.  Good American Strong flavours, but without the harsh alcohol of many of the others.  Resiny, pine sap bitterness and orange zest dominate the tongue.  The finish is much sweeter than I would have expected with a bit of cherry and vanilla cream.  Very tastyI also had this one tap and felt that the flavours were a bit more pronounced and the palate better developed than the bottled version.
12oz bottle.  Clear and ruby.  White head.  sugary floral nose.  Caramel and cola.  Hoppy with sweet malts and a slight burn.  Touch of rye bread.

First of all, this beer will always live in the shadow of Bear RepublicsHop Rod Rye.  Its the same idea, and is just a touch inferior.  However, both are really good beers.  This one is soapy and smooth with a nice full malty body.  Perfect hop bitterness in the back.  Nice crisp rye all the way through to the finish.  That palm sugar does give a smooth vanilla touch, but I probably wouldnt have picked it up if I didnt know it was in there.  Maybe could actually use more hops.  The aroma is really strong with floral and citrus, but the flavor is different.  Theyre definitely in there, but nice and piney.  Funny how that rye turns juicy citrus into pine.  There is some juicy citrus too.  Still, a little weaker on the hops than the BR Hop Rod.  Regardless, a really really tasty beer.  I would (and will) absolutely buy more of this stuff.

This is a really good rye beer.  The pour is a reddish color with an off-white head.  The aroma is heavy in the hops department with some spice coming through from the rye.  The taste is full and complex with plenty of the big summit hops coming through followed by a warm, spicey punch from the rye malt.  Reminds me quite a bit of Bear Republics Hop Rod Rye--and its almost that good.

On tap @ Red Bones.  Pours a dark redish brown.  Fairly opaque with small creamy head.  Aroma is strong of piney hops.  Taste is more mellow on the hops then suggested by the aroma.  Good balance of citrusy hops and smooth malts w/cherry, caramel, and bready flavors.  Thats a damn good ale.

Solid brew!  Pours a deep copper, with a nice off-white head and good lacing.  Grapefruit and pine forest in the nose, which are also reflected on the tongue.  Nice palate, some carbonation, refreshing cold.  Some rye bread in the undertones.  Great with summer barbecue.  Awesome name and label.

Citrus and earthy hop aroma.  some spicy rye.  Medium to light bodied, good bitterness, clean,  Dry because of the sugar and spicy from the rye.  This is darn good, If this were all malt it would be much less satisfying, and much less drinkable.   Good stuff.

Dark amber color.  Smell of sugar, spice, hops, rye and apricots.  Taste of rye, tons of spicey hops, some citrus and a wonderful dry bitterness.  I like this beer but its not as good as Founders Red Rye, but still enjoyable.  Have to buy some more!

22oz - Aroma of hops, malt, carmel, and rye with some alcohol.  Pours deep red/brown with a ring for head and decent lacing.  Flavor is more malt than hops, but the snap of hops is still there.  Rye, carmel, citrus, and alcohol round it out.  Palate is tart and crisp.  Different and tasty

Bottle: Deep red in color, with an off white head. Aroma, earthy hops a little resinous, some caramel. Flavor, floral and earthy with some citrus. Very hoppy and bitter on the finish. I was craving hops after quite a few malt laden beers, this delivered. And really how can you go wrong with summit and simcoe.

bottle. Pours a cloudy blood red with a very pretty, rocky white head. Intense piny hops are easily detected in the nose along with a thick, exotic sweetness like melons. More ordinary scents of grapefruit and caramel are there as well. This is aggressively hoppy in an unfamilar way. It doesnt quite have that foresty brightness, or a plastic astringency, rather its clean and it cuts like a knife. The underlying sweeter notes are mostly buried but noticed enough so the brew is not completely unbalanced. It finishes woody with a hint of berries. Nice.
Amber color with a thick light tan head. Aroma of piney hops. Flavor of piney hops and rye. Long dry bitter finish.

(05.27.06) CASK-CONDITIONED VERSION at Firkin, Libertyville, IL. Poured clear red amber with giant white head. No discernable carbonation. Soft hop bouquet. Medium bodied red rye ale that starts dry with citrusy (grapefruit) hop flavor. Finished with light hop bitterness. Resembles a toned-down version of 3Fs Alpha King. Smooth and delicious.  BOTTLE VERSION from DiCarlos, Mundelein, IL. One pint, 6 oz brown bottle. 7% ABV. 17 P, 68 IBU.  Hop aroma. Medium bodied clear red amber ale with average size head. Soft carbonation. Start with light malt sweetness and spicy hoppy flavors. Finished with lingering hop flavor and slight bitterness. Well-balanced and smooth. Both bottle and cask-condition versions were excellent but I thought the bottle version tasted slightly better than cask-condition version.  The rating is the average of both versions.

Bottle. Poured hazy copper with an average fizzy white head that lasted and produced good lacing. Moderate complex sweet citrus and rye aroma. Medium body with a creamy texture. Medium balanced hoppy flavor with a medium rye tingly bitter finish of moderate duration.  Solid complex beer.

From a 22 oz. brown bomber with a blurb on the upper right corner of label, no bottled freshness.

Poured a slightly hazy reddish brown with a foamy off-white that settled into a thin sudsy lacing, minimal amount of sticking.

Aromas of pineapple and orange mixed with pine, a light rye spiciness.

Moderate carbonation and a soft crisp and textured medium bodied mouthfeel.

Spicy rye bready with pine and caramel, the Thai palm sugar gives it a tropical fruitiness, the hops give it a nice sour pine and pepper taste, and a dryish rye bready and hoppy finish. The alcohol provides a good warmth in the palate, but otherwise is well masked, only faintly shows up in the spiciness. Good overall drinkability.

This is, by far, my favorite in the limited run series from Two Brothers, I would recommend picking more than a few of these, should make good trade bait.

aroma was malt and cola at first,followed quickly by citrusy hops and rye, medium copper color, quickly diminishing head, hops rye malt and sugar in the taste,body seemed to be a little thin little bit of sweetness in the aftertaste,big beer like this should have more malt,but I did love the hops and rye.

22oz bomber, been wanting to try this for a while.  Pours a crystal reddish brown with a small light beige head.  Aroma of pine and grapefruity hops, some spiciness, and some caramel malts.  Grapefruity and piney flavor, with some caramel malts in the background.  Taste is quite spicy in the finish, pretty big bitterness throughout.  I kinda wish that they dry hopped this with the Summit as well, as I cant tell which flavors are the Summit and which are the Simcoe, since they seem fairly similar.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Although my expectations were not high, I had hoped for a decent offering from the bros.  This is a very unique and delicious beer.  Carmel malts like a typical red, but finishes dry with a big hop presence.  I am now very interested in using both rye malts and the new Summit hops in my home brews.  This beer summed up can be described as an Imperial, hoppy Red.

rating #700.  an interesting blend of rye flavors and hop flavors of pink grapefruit.  pours a near fire red amber with a good sized head.  aromas and flavors are of the aforementioned rye and grapefruit with some caramel malt and finishes rather sweet.

Dark amber-rudy color with a inch of tight tiny taupe bubbles. Hugh grapefruit and light sweet fruits in the aroma. Mild pine and a smidgen of rye bread also floating about. A true hopshead aroma. Somewhat silky on the palate, but also seems a bit lifeless. Sweet ruby red grapefruit flavors start things off. Some light melon and orange also. Mid quaff brings some dark caramel, vanilla and rye. Rather sharp finish with a light pepper burn that continues through to the linger. Linger also has a simple sugar flavor with a creme brule quality. Aside from the sharpness at points an enjoyable hopshead brew.

Pour is a dark red with a large white head.  Aroma is strong amounts of rye with some hops to even out the bitterness.  Flavor is a nice mix of hops and cane sugar.  Very pleasing to all the sences.  Of all the "rye" beers i have had this is prob the only one i could actually taste and smell the rye used.  Very good and satisfying.

22 oz. bottle.  Poured a clear, deep fiery red with a cap of off-white head.  I really enjoyed the nose on this one... big, juicy pear and citrus with spicy rye and sweet maltage.  Juicy again in the flavor, and damn sweet... pine, citrus, and peary hoppage provides a very high level of bitterness all around... caramel, palm sugar, and spiced-up rye form a solid base.  Very good, but a tad too sweet for me.  Lighter on the palate... and a tad tacky at the finish.  Wonderful hoppage level.  Very good stuff!

Pours a bright medium brown/dark amber with an antique lace head that diminishes, yet stays at the surface and coats somewhat.  Aroma is grapefruit and spiciness of the dry hopping.  Taste is caramely malt, the bitterness of the hops, and the crisp texture of the rye.  A hopheads delight, but very well balanced and flavorful.

On tap:  This is hoppy, my guess is beyond the range detectable by the human palate, or at the very least my palate.  Deep red moderate carbonation.  The rye is understated, unlike some of the brews put out by Founders, for instance.  If paring with food, make sure the food is bold and flavorful.

Tap at the Map room: Pours a deep gusset red with a thick lasting head. Aroma is heavily spicy. Hug notes of rye and a pleasant dry-hopped piny character. The body is med-heavy and filling. The flavors are dominated by the rye but is entirely pleasant. There is a punch of citrusy piney hops that really balance all that rye spiciness. Finish is highly bitter. Great beer!

Copper/amber with a moderate frothy white head.  Deli rye, caraway, ginger, pepper, brown sugar in the nose.  Medium body and gentle carbonation.  The flavor was appealing.  Nice blend of sweet and spicy.  Not been fond of Two Brothers offerings but this was quite good.

Thought I would go with an interesting one for number 300 & this one definitely fit the bill.  Pours deep brown with a frothy tan head with nice retention & lacing.  Aroma has a strange hoppiness - grassy, piney, little bits of raw sugar and a rich smell I cant put my finger on.  Its probably the Thai palm sugar as Im not sure what that smells like.  Medium mouthfeel with light carbonation.  Very interesting taste here, espcially being from Two Brothers.  Hop taste all the way through, quite woody, but not as intense as chinook.  The beer is more dry than expected for having sugar added - it is fairly sharp tasting.  Nice rye dryness on the finish.  There is also a unique bitterness.  Further down the glass there seems to be a bit of creamy / vanilla flavor.  Even further down some sweetness comes out that compliments the hops and rye very well.  Very well done, probably the best Ive had from Two Brothers.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2007 On cask at Tumans.  Pours dark red with a thick off white head.  Sweet malty rye aroma with hop spice.  Roasted rye, sweet malt flavors with a surprising amount of hops that left it still smooth but very slightly bitter in the end.  Full body and almost chewy on cask.  Good in the bottle but damn good on cask.  very well executed.

Deep mahogany pour, with a medium head and decent lace.  Definitive grass-hop nose, pine and rye bread that all permeate the flavor.  The combo is interesting here... such unique and powerful flavors make me think the mouthfeel should be heavier than the brew provides.  As the beer warms, I pick up grapefruit and pine notes... especially pine.  It feels a tad thinner than I expected; the back palate is highlighted with a peppered bitterness in the finish.  If I had to guess, I would say it mimics an IPA, sort of.... just not as robust.  It is a bit lighter.  Very unique brew, though...

<!-- i -->22 oz. Bottle.<!-- /i --> Interesting pour. Belgian type sugary smell accented by a grassy spicy hop nose. Pours nice brown which lets light shine through red, and lots of pinprick bubbles. Taste is a nice spicy surprise. I dont know if I can pick out a rye beer blind, but this has a definite rye bread taste. Sweetness is not overdone, except for slightly masking the slightly Scots malts. The hops I find really intriguing, like Amarillo whupped by pine branches. A combination of lots of big flavors, all working together in some weird way. I cant find the alcohol either, but I suspect I will notice it later.

Draft. Pours a light amber with a thin white head.  The aroma is piney, floral with citrus notes, a bit of grapefruit and orange.  Is this thing a Pale Ale?  The flavor starts out like a pale ale as well.  A nice hop balance with some caramel malts to even things out.  This beer tasted good, but I swear it is a pale ale and not a strong ale. Maybe it is this high amount of hops.  Still a tasty brew.

Red and brown with a fluffy, off-white head.  The aroma is crazy pine and grapefruit notes with some sweet caramel, heavy toasted grains, orange zest, spicy rye bread and virtually no alcohol.  The nose when from the bottle is so much better than the nose on draft.  The body is actually a little thin and better when on draft than in the bottle.  When in the mouth, the flavor starts sweet and has some nice punch.  The finish shows some nice, balanced, flavorful hop bitterness and tasty fruit elements.  The alcohol is undectable and the flavors are smooth and highly enjoyable.  Im generally a little disappointed by some of the beers from Two Brothers, but this is one of the better ones Ive had.  After a few draught samples and (at least) one bomber, I prefer the bottle despite the thinner body.

Bomber. Blah. Boo. These guys never fail to dissapoint me, I dont know why I keep giving them a chance. Poured an amber red, lots of bubbles, soapy white head. Highly filtered. Nose is some faint hops and bready malt. Taste is soapy (not from my glass). Light malts and hops. Yep, nothing much to this one. Rye is barely present. Boring and uninspiring.

Pours a dark red with a clear body leaving a thin white lace for a head. The smell is spicy hops, citrus, earthy bread tones, and finishes with a sugar cane taste that is very apparent. The taste is sweet, it starts with a bitter hop bite that is smooth and balanced with the cane sweetness and a cereal undertone this is a very interesting beer one that is easily one of my favorite rye beers. The combination of rye and hops is fantastic, I hope this brew is here to stay.

Clear, light red-brown, with a negligible white head. Really wonderful nose of caramel and toffee, with lovely fruity notes of grapefruit and apricots. Flavor is quite fruity as well, somewhere between the peach/nectarine spectrum and the orange/grapefruit continuum, with a solid bitter kick. I suppose there is a spicy tang in there as well--but if thats rye or hops, Im not to say.

Two Brothers continues to impress with another special edition beer. I cannot figure out why this brewery does not get more hype. The body was dark amber with a slightly off white colored head. The aroma had lots of rye with some toffee. There was also some classic grapefruit. The taste was toasty with some rye. There was also grapefruit with some bread crust. A very well made and interesting beer. Keep it up, Two Brothers!

One of TBs better offerings, appealing to my hophead side.  It pours a deep, brownish-orange body with a modest light tan head.  The aroma has the peppery spiciness of rye along with herbs and a piney/earthy hoppiness.  Nice and thick in the mouth, slightly oily, with a mild spicy burn to it.  The flavor is a solid blend of dark caramel, rye, pine, white pepper, soil, herbs, and a lingering bitterness... the part that appeals to me most. Bottle.  First smell is of some gingery, hop scents, and some sticky pine sap aromas as well.  Texture is moderately thick, a little grassy hop note in there as well, and some canola oil flavors.  A little bit of some hoppy rye noticed, finishes slightly thin but has some tang to it. Decent.

Pour is clear golden with a thin off white head....smell is pine and sweetness...taste is sweet at first with some strong bitterness coming up at the finish...a little thin and somewhat vegetal in the finish...

Cream?  Thai??  I dont get that, but this is fantastic.  Sweet and spicy, thats for sure.  Bit-o-Honey meets a Clark bar.  Awesome if you like Rye.  Seems like some Amarillo, maybe.  Tomahawk?  Someone please tell the Ebel brothers to follow through on their thoughts and make this one year-round and available in sixers, please.  Awesome.
(22oz bottle)  Pours a clear dark amber body with a small beige head.  Aroma of strong fresh pine and sugarcane.  Flavor of toasted malt, mild hops, and sugar.

Pine sap body. Nose was pine sap.  Flavour was pine sap, with some notes of juniper berries, with piney hops.  After taste is like sucking on a mop that was used to clean out a pine mulcher using extra strength pinesol, with a pine twist.

Bottle at 2006 Chromefest: brownish pour with a medium sized off white head. Kind of a rye bread, ammonia aroma with pine and stink weed. Piney rye flavor that struck me as odd at first but became something I thought was quite nice at the end. I liked it.

Bottle. Nose-urine, jaggery, mild hops, pine tar resin. Brown body with a loose ring of bubbles. Taste-medium bitter, tannic, woody, rye, pine. An odd mix of unpleasant and pleasant. Sharp and exotic.

Pine strong in the aroma with the sugar there too.  Clear wood brown color with some yellow.  The flavor is malty, sweet, some cigarette ashes, the hoppiness emergent after five seconds but not exceptionally strong, though it lingers for a time.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2006 Draught pint at Redbones on 6/1/06.Deep auburn-amber red, with light gold highlights.  Head is medium sized at first, frothy, off-white and mostly diminishing to cover, with minor lacing.  High clarity, but not crystal clear, with some glassiness to itFruitiness overwhelms (in a good way) in the nose.  Juicy fruits, cherries, strawberries and lightly leafy, juicy hop buds all surge forward, clinging to the nose and allowing the dry, lightly peppery rye notes to slip in on the backend.  Malt is lightly toasty, with a fair dose of sugariness that seems well-suited to the fruity hops.  As it warms and breathes, the aroma dries out somewhat, with a definite perfuminess that I associate with rye, but perhaps incorrectly so, as it could just be some bitter hop acids.  Strength is medium to medium-high and well persistent to the end of the glassThe flavor is no less hoppy, though fortunately for the balance, it is mostly flavoring hops, without the stinging, acidic bitterness.  Rye is lightly nutty, but only coming on in the middle.  The very first sip is lightly chocolatey, with a creamy, engaging mouthfeel that seems both more sweet and deep than Founders Reds Rye.  Not to burst Two Brothers bubble, but this is certainly not far removed from Reds Rye.  A highly hopped red ipa with rye, it certainly is well done.  Fluffy, nearly creamy vanilla-cream sweetness lasts on the finish, as a minor touch of bready malts begin to dry things.  Leafy, fuzzy hops linger on, not as fruity as the beginning, but still bitter and pleasing to the palate, creating balance to the sweet malts.  No alcohol noted in flavor or aroma.  A touch more thin upon warming, but no doubt due to the draught nature (looser carbonation).

Draught pint at Red Bones 6/1/06. Pours a nice amber color with a small off white head. Nose is floral and spicy hops with a nice rye touch to it. Palate is crisp but with a nice creamy smoothness to it. Flavor is heavy on the rye with a very nice fresh hop bite to it. Some notes of caramel and sweet malt make an appearance in the backround.
Amber collor with a nice size head.  Lots of citrus/pine hop aroma.  Rye spiciness definitely there.  Nice blalance in the flavor.  I think this is the brewerys best effort to date.

i just gonna defer to zeswafts description of this beer.  the only thing i really have to add to that is that i thought this was an amber.  but i didnt realize it was 7% abv.  i didnt think it was as great as he did either.  definitely could taste the rye.

I was pretty drunk when I drank this but I remember it being quite fantastic.  Lots of citrus hops and slightly spiced from the rye.  Reminded me a lot of Founders Reds Rye.  It looks like the people at Two Brothers are figuring out how to brew some great beers.

On tap at The Map Room.  Pours a modest amber with a thin white head.  Big hop aromas of grapefruit, pine, etc.  The rye lends some nice spice qualities to this hopped up brew.  Finishes a bit astringent but is quite enjoyable.

Wahoo, first one in the pool ! On tap at the Sunset Grille. Good nose, sweet & spicy. Fruity, orange, tangerine, grapefruit with rye. Clean orange amber color, small head that faded to a ring, with good lacing. Bitter sweet flavor. Grapefruit kicks in, orange, pine too. rye shows itself. Medium body, creamy oily mouthfeel, bittersweet dryish finish. Nice brew, rye and over the top hops just work so well together.
